resources.string:
This metric shows the demand for the system's CPU and represents the average number of processes that are:
• Currently using the CPU
• Waiting to use the CPU
• Waiting for IO or disk access
Should be a number in the interval 5–200
Time interval between the end of a sample and the beginning of the next one. Keep in mind that generating a sample can also take up to 1 second, if thread count information is included.
Time interval (in milliseconds) between two consecutive samples for home screen
Period of time that is accounted for when calculating the CPU load. This applies to both home screen and live chart
Time interval (in milliseconds) between two consecutive samples for memory and CPU live charts
Period of time (in seconds) that is tracked by memory and CPU live charts
Period of time (in hours) that is tracked by the battery level live chart
Maximum number of power and performance recording results displayed in the list
Controls whether a notification is sent when a recording session ends

It is recommended to turn off Wi-Fi during long periods of inactivity (such as during the night), at the same time making sure that Mobile Data connection is disabled. In case you forget to do so, Power Manager will automatically disable Wi-Fi when the device enters Doze mode (a state of deep sleep triggered by long periods of inactivity).
\u2022 Enabling Dark Theme can also extend your battery life, especially on devices with OLED or AMOLED displays.

\tScaling governors are a part of the Linux CPU frequency scaling subsystem that periodically compute the optimum frequency for CPU cores and set it, based on different strategies.\n\tSome well known scaling governors are:

\u2022 The display is one of the most important battery drain sources on mobile devices. Reducing its brightness can have a great impact on battery life. If you want automatic adjustments of the brightness level based on the environmental lighting, you can enable Adaptive Brightness.
\u2022 A Screen Timeout value as small as possible is another way to save battery.
Include thread count statistics (might significantly increase total session duration)

The \'performance\' governor keeps each core at its maximum available frequency at all times. It is suitable for computationally intensive tasks such as image editing or playing complex video games, but it may consume more power.

The \'powersave\' governor keeps each core at its minimum available frequency at all times. While it is likely to reduce power consumption, the performance of the device might be strongly affected. It is suitable for tasks such as reading a PDF file.

The \'ondemand\' governor dynamically adjusts the CPU frequency based on the system load. It increases the frequency when the system is under heavy load and decreases it when the load decreases. It aims to balance performance and power consumption.
The \'userspace\' governor allows users to manually set the CPU frequency of each core.

The \'interactive\' governor controls the CPU frequency based on the detection of user interactions: it will quickly ramp up the frequency when user interactions are detected and will reduce the frequency when there are no interactions.

The \'conservative\' governor dynamically adjusts the CPU frequency based on the system load. It gradually increases the frequency in response to increased load and decreases it slowly as the load decreases.

The \'schedutil\' governor uses information provided by the scheduler (another component of the Operating System) to make decisions about CPU frequency changes, such as predicting future workload demands and adjusting the frequency accordingly.
Click here for more information on scaling governors:
